name: Kedarnath Jyotirlinga
description: Located in the Garhwal Himalayas in Uttarakhand. One of the Char Dham pilgrimage sites. Situated at an altitude of 3,583 meters near the Mandakini River.
notes: Part of Char Dham, opens only from April to November

name: Trimbakeshwar Jyotirlinga
description: Located near Nashik, Maharashtra in the Trimbak region. The temple is at the source of the Godavari River. The Jyotirlinga here has three faces representing Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva.
notes: Source of Godavari river, Jyotirlinga with three faces

name: Rameshwaram Jyotirlinga
description: Located in Rameswaram on Pamban Island, Tamil Nadu. One of the Char Dham pilgrimage sites. The southernmost Jyotirlinga, connected to the Ramayana epic.
notes: Southernmost Jyotirlinga, part of Char Dham

name: Grishneshwar Jyotirlinga
description: Located near the Ellora Caves in Aurangabad district, Maharashtra. The last or 12th Jyotirlinga. Close to the UNESCO World Heritage Site of Ellora.
notes: 12th Jyotirlinga, near UNESCO World Heritage Ellora Caves

name: Kamakshi Shakti Peeth
description: Temple in Kanchipuram, Tamil Nadu. Navel/Back of Goddess Sati fell here.

name: Sabarimala Temple
description: Famous temple dedicated to Lord Ayyappa, located in the Western Ghats of Kerala. One of the largest annual pilgrimages in the world with millions of devotees.
notes: Sacred shrine of Lord Ayyappa in the hills

name: Guruvayur Sri Krishna Temple
description: One of the most important Krishna temples in South India, known as 'Bhuloka Vaikunta' (the holy abode of Vishnu on Earth). Famous for its strict traditional practices.
notes: Dwarka of the South, famous Krishna temple

name: Meenakshi Amman Temple
description: Historic Hindu temple dedicated to Goddess Meenakshi and Lord Sundareshwar (Shiva). Famous for its stunning architecture with 14 gopurams (towers), intricate sculptures and paintings.

name: Brihadeeswarar Temple
description: UNESCO World Heritage Site built by Chola emperor Raja Raja I in 1010 CE. Dedicated to Lord Shiva, famous for its massive 216 feet tall vimana (tower) and Nandi statue.
notes: Great Living Chola Temple, architectural marvel

name: Manakula Vinayagar Temple
description: Ancient temple dedicated to Lord Ganesha in Pondicherry. Known for the temple elephant and French colonial architecture influence. Important pilgrimage site.
notes: Famous Ganesha temple in French quarter

name: Shore Temple
description: UNESCO World Heritage Site, built in 8th century CE during Pallava dynasty. One of the oldest structural stone temples in South India, located on the Bay of Bengal shore.
notes: Ancient shore temple, Pallava architectural masterpiece

name: Arunachaleswarar Temple
description: Ancient and sacred temple dedicated to Lord Shiva in Tiruvannamalai, Tamil Nadu. One of the Pancha Bhoota Stalas representing the element of fire. Famous for the Annamalai Hill and Girivalam circumambulation path.
notes: Pancha Bhoota Stala (Fire element), Annamalai Hill, Girivalam path

name: Chennakeshava Temple
description: Magnificent Hindu temple in Belur, Karnataka, dedicated to Lord Vishnu. Built in 1117 CE by Hoysala King Vishnuvardhana. Masterpiece of Hoysala architecture with intricate sculptures and carvings. UNESCO World Heritage Site.
notes: 12th century Hoysala masterpiece, UNESCO World Heritage Site, intricate carvings

name: Chikkamagaluru
description: Scenic hill station in Karnataka, known as the 'Coffee Land of Karnataka'. Famous for coffee plantations, mountains, waterfalls, and trekking destinations like Mullayanagiri (highest peak in Karnataka) and Baba Budangiri hills.
notes: Coffee Land of Karnataka, Mullayanagiri peak, Baba Budangiri hills

name: Kukke Subramanya Temple
description: Ancient Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Subramanya (Kartikeya) located in Subramanya, Karnataka. Famous pilgrimage site in the Western Ghats, known for Sarpa Samskara (serpent worship rituals). Temple is situated on the banks of Kumaradhara River.
notes: Famous for Sarpa Samskara rituals, Western Ghats, Kumaradhara River

name: Dharmasthala Manjunatha Temple
description: Famous Hindu temple dedicated to Lord Manjunatha (form of Shiva) in Dharmasthala, Karnataka. Unique temple managed by a Jain administration. Known for its religious harmony, charity services, and free meals (Annadana) served to thousands daily.
notes: Unique Jain-managed Shiva temple, famous for religious harmony and Annadana
